characters: H I F R EW D
-- BECAUSE SARAH'S BEING LIFTED KICKING AND SCREAMING OFF
INTO THE UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. THE BEDROOM DOOR SLAMMING SHUT
-- THAT HER CAR NOW SITS SMACK DAB IN THE MIDDLE OF THE
TIME DISSOLVE. FROM THE SHINING LIGHT OF THE CAMPING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cars in the driveway. A single light on in an upstairs window. We hear A TEENAGE GIRL’S VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk. I felt like last night... I don’t know. Things were starting to get kinda weird between us. EASE IN on that upstairs window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glimpse a sliver of A BEDROOM... because we’re looking ou from inside the bedroom closet. The slightly open closet door keeps us from seeing more. We stay exactly in this spot throughout... A teen girl sits on the floor. This is DEBBIE (17). She’s talking to someone in her room.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: It was fun for a while, when we first started playing. But... I feel like you've changed. EASE OVER SLIGHTLY... able to see a little more of Debbie There’s something in front of her on the floor. A GAME BOARD. Debbie’s fingers touching a heart-shaped wooden pi on the board. She's playing OUIJA with someone. But from where we are inside the closet, we can’t see who it is. WE DRIFT UP AWAY FROM THE BOARD now so that we’re just on Debbie’s face.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, you’re still my friend, right? Debbie sits there waiting.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon. Answer me. Suddenly, Debbie’s expression shifts. Fear in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what? This is our last game. I’m not playing ever again. I want you to leave. Just get out. MOVEMENT. A DARK SHAPE steps past the crack in the close We hear a THUD and now we are --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM WITH DEBBIE
dialogues.text: She sits there alone on the floor, glancing over to the w open bedroom door as it comes to a rest against the wall. if someone just left the room. The night wind creaks outside... Debbie gathers up the Ouija board and planchette and move quickly to her closet. She opens the double doors, about put the board away when -- -- there's a noise. SCRAPE. Debbie glances over her shoulder. The room is still empty. She turns back. Reaching to place the Ouija up on a shelf behind her -- -- there's MOVEMENT in a mirror. Unseen by Debbie, becaus she’s still reaching up to put the board away. The wooden planchette slips and falls, landing at Debbie’ feet. She picks it up when suddenly -- -- BAM! A loud sound in her room. Debbie spins to see tha her bedside table lamp has fallen... now slowly rolling o the floor. Debbie stands there totally still. Staring. Her panicked eyes scan the room. All we hear is her BREATHING and the WIND outside. She turns slightly... and a SHADOW falls across her face. We don’t see what she sees -- but someon standing right there. Debbie stares. Absolutely terrified. Her lips tremble, about to say something when -- -- she’s PUSHED HARD into her closet! It’s a blur. She falls back into her hanging clothes. Getting twisted up i plastic dry cleaning bag. VERY CLOSE on Debbie -- and right before she can scream, clear plastic dry cleaning bag suddenly PRESSES TIGHT AGA HER FACE! A split second shock and we instantly go -- INT. DEBBIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT -- back into the bedroom. The closet doors, out of focus the background. We catch the tail end of them closing shu with a slight creak. No sound comes from the closet. Just the wind outside. CHILLING MUSIC rises, taking us to -- TITLE CREDITS. A vintage turn of the century black and w photograph of a parlor SEANCE GATHERING. People in formal attire at a table with a OUIJA BOARD at the center. We he a WOMAN’S VOICE speak via a scratchy cylinder recording - WOMAN’S VOICE As friends we've gathered, hearts are true. Spirits near, we call to you. More PHOTOS. STOCK FILM FOOTAGE. Moving through the decades. Groups of people playing the Ouija. Even though the times and styles change, the Ouija board continues to look the same. We hear that familiar calling, different

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS VOICES
dialogues.text: As friends we've gathered, hearts are true. Spirits near, we call to you. Polaroid shots. Video footage. Each Ouija game feels more recent than the last. The final image is TWO GIRLS (12). Sitting on a floor with a Ouija board between them. Dress for a sleepover. It’s just a photo, but we hear their innocent young voices as they say the words --

dialogues.speaker: TWO GIRLS
dialogues.text: As friends we've gathered, hearts are true. Spirits near, we call to you. From the photo of the two girls we DRIP TO BLACK. LARGE B LETTERS appear one by one out of the darkness... as if conjured from the ether. Spelling out a single mysterious word in a familiar vintage font:

dialogues.speaker: OUIJA
dialogues.text: SOUND rises. A hard SCRATCHING. CLOSE ON -- A PENCIL ON PAPER. Cursive handwriting spills across the page. Beat. Suddenly the paper is ripped from a notebook and crumpled

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELENA “LAINE” MORENO, 17, tosses the paper into the wastebasket near her desk. A few other crumpled notes already in there. It's early. Laine sits alone in the classroom. Outside th commotion of students arriving for the school day. Laughi distant voices. Slamming of lockers out in the hallway.  Laine regards another blank piece of paper. She takes a breath. Writes out another note. Her final words are the only ones we see: “Friends forever xoxo Laine” Laine folds the paper into an origami note. She sets it o far desk near the window as the bell rings and students s filtering into the classroom. A MOMENT LATER. Laine’s back in her desk. ISABELLE (17) takes the seat next to her and starts right in --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What are we feeling this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It’s only Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I know. But I like to get a jump. (scrolling through her phone) Got multiple party options here. Small selective gathering or that blow-out everyone’s going to? A GUY swoops in and gives Laine a kiss before taking the behind her. This is TREVOR (17).

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: She trying to steal my time again? Iz, we don’t always have to tag along. You can fly solo.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me showing up to a party alone wouldn’t look pathetic at all. Not everyone has your perfect couple situation.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Look at her... acting like she's not the one who breaks up with every guy she goes out with.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I’m a picky bitch. Can’t help it. A TEACHER, MR. SATLOF, enters and starts passing out an e

dialogues.speaker: MR. SATLOF
dialogues.text: Okay. Settle. Books away. I’m putting thirty minutes on the clock. Please dazzle me with your knowledge of all things John Milton. Trevor leans in toward Laine, whispering --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo. You ready to throw down on this iambic pentameter -- But Laine’s not paying attention. She’s glancing back at desk where she put the note... and it’s still empty. The note just sitting there. TREVOR (CONT’D) Laine? This is the part where you laugh. Laine snaps out of it. Gives Trevor a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SATLOF
dialogues.text: Eyes front. No talking.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: LAINE TAKING HER TEST. She hears whispering and looks up see her TEACHER out in the hall talking with someone. Mr. Satlof comes back into the classroom, and by his somb expression, Laine knows that something is wrong. MR. SATLOF (CONT’D) I know some of you are finishing up, but... I have something I need to share with everyone. Students put their pencils down. Murmuring, wondering wha going on. MR. SATLOF (CONT’D) I just got word that... Mr. Satlof’s voice trails off. This is hard for him to sa Laine glances back again at the EMPTY DESK. Then --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It's Debbie, isn’t it? What happened? Now everyone’s looking at Laine. Mr. Satlof slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SATLOF
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry... she died at her house last night.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Reaction ripples through the classroom. Isabelle starts crying. But Laine is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It’s a mistake. Debbie can’t be dead...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SATLOF
dialogues.text: This is a tremendous loss. The school will be providing counselors for anyone who needs to talk during this difficult time -- EASE IN ON LAINE. Her eyes stare in shock. The world suddenly seems to swim around her. Sounds and voices fadi And from that EMPTY DESK with the note sitting on it we g INT. LAINE’S ROOM - DAY Laine stands at a mirror as an OLDER WOMAN zips up her bl dress from behind. This is Laine’s grandmother, NONA. The woman sees the devastation on her granddaughter’s fac Their conversations are always in Spanish with subtitles

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: I know this mourning that you feel. With the death of a friend, there is a part of you who dies as well.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It's like there's a pain in my heart that will never go away.

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: Respect grief, my precious Elena. It is often in these times we find our own light and understanding. Laine looks at her grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I don't want understanding. I want Debbie back. There’s a knock at the door. Laine’s father, ANTHONY MORE Latino. Dressed in a suit. His eyes filled with heartache

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORENO
dialogues.text: It’s time. EXT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - DAY Several cars are parked out front. GUESTS in post-funeral attire heading into the house.  INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - DOWNSTAIRS - DAY WITH LAINE. Standing among the mourners who are gathered the house. Adults. Other high school friends. A few teachers... Mr. Satlof among them. Trevor and Isabelle ar here. Laine moves through the gathering. Voices hushed. Snippet of dialogue:

dialogues.speaker: MOURNERS, (VARIOUS)
dialogues.text: -..and that Carol had to find her like that... in the closet. Just horrible... makes no sense. They're packed and coming to stay with me... can’t be in this house another night... Laine hovers, glances at a vintage ANNIVERSARY CLOCK. Sma crack in the glass dome. Hands frozen in time. Hasn’t worked in years. Beat... then over at the stairs she sees a GUY standing t holding flowers. Student. Strange. Thrift store suit and tie. He doesn’t seem to know anyone else here. He’s just standing there. Glancing up the stairs... Laine hears crying. Sees Debbie’s PARENTS sitting across house, being comforted by friends. THE MOTHER, sobbing. Laine turns back... and now that GUY at the bottom of the stairs is gone. His flowers left behind on the foyer tabl INT. DEBBIE’S ROOM - DAY Upstairs. Laine pushes open a door into Debbie’s bedroom. She steps inside and glances around, as if trying to understand Debbie’s sudden death. The room is decorated in an eclectic style. Evidence of Debbie’s life in high school theatre. Framed posters and photos of her plays and performances. But the most promin feature in the room is a MURAL OF A TREE, silhouette styl Painted branches sweeping across the wall. It’s familiar. We’ve been in this room before... Laine casts a glance to the closet. The door is slightly open. An unsettling crack of darkness within. Laine reach out and pushes it closed. Laine takes a breath. She steps to a BULLETIN BOARD, cove in mementos and photos. Almost all of the pictures are of Debbie and Laine. Through the years. Birthday parties. Camping trips. School dances. Arms around each other. A faint CREAK. Laine looks over... and the closet door i again slightly open. She stares... unaware that a FIGURE now right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You were everything to her. Laine spins and sees Debbie’s MOTHER standing there. The woman’s eyes wild with grief.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Mrs. G... (devastating beat) I can’t believe she’s gone. Laine hugs Debbie’s mom. Holds her tight in the silence. And then Mrs. Galardi pulls back, looks at Laine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: Do you understand this, Laine? Why would my baby do this to herself? Tears run down Laine’s cheeks. All of this simply too muc

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Mrs. Galardi steps away... glances around. Being in this room, the despair is so immense. Mrs. Galardi starts collecting some of her daughter’s possessions and putting them in a box. A bracelet. An old Flip camera. Pulling photos from the bulletin board. Laine watches her with concern, not understanding. LAINE (CONT’D) Mrs. G....

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: She’d want you to have these. This way a part of her is always with you... Mrs. Galardi hands Laine the box of mementos.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Always remember her. Laine nods. Her heart breaking. EXT. LAINE’S HOUSE - NIGHT A very similar two-story style as Debbie’s house. Same neighborhood. The sudden SOUND OF GIRLS LAUGHING takes us FLIP CAMERA VIDEO SCREEN. Recent footage. Laine and Debb trying on dresses in a small store changing room. Laughin Posing in the mirror. Hamming it up for the camera.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: That's the one. Very hot. Lemme see that booty shake!

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies, I need you to keep it down in there. We do have other customers. Laine and Debbie laugh so hard they can barely breathe. ANOTHER MOMENT. Laine and Debbie in their dresses. In Debbie's house. Saying goodbye to Debbie's parents. ANOTHER MOMENT. School dance. Music pumping. Lights swirling. Debbie holds the camera out, getting a two-shot her and Laine. The kind of night you want to last forever Image freezes. A GLITCH. It makes Debbie's frozen laugh look like a scream. INT. LAINE’S ROOM - NIGHT Laine’s on her bed with the box of mementos. Laptop open next to her revealing Debbie’s Facebook page -- now a memorial. Memories and messages from friends popping up. Laine tries to get the Flip camera working again, but it’ stuck on that image of Debbie. Laine sets it aside. She looks down at the mementos. Laine puts Debbie’s infin charm bracelet on her wrist. She dangles a little penguin with sunglasses keychain on her finger... ..-when she hears a loud car MUFFLER outside. Laine goes to the window. Her sister SARAH (15) emerges f a beat-up car that proceeds to head off down the street. The girl comes up the sidewalk as Laine’s FATHER storms o of the house. Laine cracks her bedroom window to listen -

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORENO
dialogues.text: -- that’s the guy you skipped school with today? What the hell’s going on with you?! Sarah responds. Her voice low. Laine unable to make it ou MR. MORENO (CONT’D) Well, you better start caring. Because I’m getting calls at work. Principal said one more no-show and you’re getting expelled --  10. Laine watches as her father follows Sarah into the house, their ARGUING VOICES muffled through the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARAH stomps up the stairs into the hallway and we get ou first real look at her. Heavy makeup. Growing up too fast Sarah sees Laine standing there.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Great. Now I get to be blessed with your opinion too. Lucky me.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you weren’t at the funeral. Actually, I can. It’s totally typical. Sarah keeps heading to her room. Laine follows.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Can’t be around people crying. All sad and stuff --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- Debbie was always good to you. Especially when mom left --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: -- I know. Okay. (beat) And now she’s gone too. Sarah steps into her room and closes the door, leaving La alone in the hallway. INT. LAINE’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Laine steps to her bed, starts putting Debbie’s things ba in the box. She glances over and sees that a PHOTO has fallen on the floor. Face down. She picks it up. It’s Laine and Debbie circa 7th grade. The two girls are their pajamas playing a OUIJA BOARD. Two girls playing Ouija. We've seen this photo. Laine stares at the photo. Lost in thought. She notices something. Runs her finger over a GLARE streaking across Ouija board in the image. It’s odd. Then -- LAINE'S COMPUTER SCREEN. Photo folders. Click. Recent Instagram pics of Laine and her friends.  11. INT. LAINE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - LATER Laine scrolls through her digital photos. Going backwards through the years. And Laine finally finds the exact same photo of her and Debbie on the floor playing the Ouija. Laine holds up the printed photo next to the image on her screen. There's no glare on her computer version. The one from Debbie's bulletin board is definitely different. CLOSE ON THE PRINTED PHOTO. Suddenly lit up with a bright FLASH OF LIGHT. Laine takes a ‘snapscan’ of the photo with her iPad. She opens up the image in her photo app and ENLARGES THE PICT She scrolls around. Down to the Ouija board. That WEIRD GLARE. Laine taps -- blows the photo up even more. The glare seems to perfectly highlight the word GOOD BYE at t bottom of the Ouija board. Off of Laine’s puzzled expression cut to -- EXT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - DAY Debbie’s house sits in late afternoon shadows. Curtains drawn. Trevor’s car pulls up in front. Laine gets out and heads around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: This’ll just be a second. I have to grab something. Trevor calls out through the rolled down window --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I thought her parents were gone? Laine doesn’t answer. Keeps walking. EXT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - BACKYARD - DAY Alone, Laine moves past a tarp covered swimming pool in t backyard. She glances up at the dark windows of the house There’s a soft lapping of water from under the pool tarp. Laine turns. A brief undulating MOVEMENT underneath... bu it’s just the wind. Dead leaves blowing across the tarp. Laine checks under a small garden statue -- finds a SPARE KEY. A hiding place she’s familiar with. And when she looks back up at the house... there’s now a LIGHT TURNED ON IN AN UPSTAIRS WINDOW. Laine looks at the window, unsettled, as we go --  12. INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - DOWNSTAIRS - DAY A CLICK at the back door... and Laine comes inside. Curta drawn. Still.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Mrs. G? Hello? No answer. Laine moves through the kitchen. Coffee cups next to an open tin of cookies... remnants of Debbie’s wa There’s a feeling that Debbie’s parents packed a few thin and simply left. So eerie. INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - DAY Laine steps to the top of the stairs. Down the hall... th LIGHT is coming from Debbie’s bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Somebody there? INT. DEBBIE’S ROOM - DAY Laine moves into Debbie’s room. Everything here is just a it was the other day. Preserved and untouched. The bedside table lamp suddenly FLICKERS off and then bac on. BUZZING like it has a bad bulb. Laine unplugs it... But now there’s a slight sound. SCRAAAPE. Laine turns -- eyes falling on the CLOSET. Is it coming from in there? She goes to the closet. Hesitates. Knowing what happened here. Laine opens the doors. Darkness. Can’t see. She reaches up, pulls the light cord --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and there’s a FACE. SOMEONE'S STANDING BEHIND THE CLEA PLASTIC HANGING BAGS. Laine startles, as --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’re you doing? Laine spins to find Trevor behind her. Watching. As Laine turns back to the closet, she sees that the “face” is actually one of Debbie’s painted theatre masks, hanging o the back wall. Laine settles, looks around the closet shelves. And there among some other games is a OUIJA BOARD. She pulls it dow and brings it over to the floor. Laine sits there, runs her fingers over the antique lette on the vintage wooden game board.  13. TREVOR (CONT’D) So you came here looking for a Ouija board?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: We used to play all the time.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Anything cool ever happen?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: No, it’s just a game. But we pretended it was real. Asked questions about our future. You know... ‘Will I ever find true love?’ Stuff like that. Debbie would always spell out the answers I needed to hear. And I'd do the same for her. Like texting each other. Old school. Trevor picks up the tear-shaped PLANCHETTE out of the box It’s wooden. Looks homemade. Not the plastic kind that usually comes with the game.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: And this is the thing you use -- the game piece?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: The planchette. Debbie’s mom made this one when she was our age. Put her initials on the bottom. And we added ours too. See? Laine places the planchette on the board. Touches it with two fingers... moving it slightly across the board -- LAINE (CONT’D) You know how Debbie and I had that huge fight a few weeks ago? Trevor nods. LAINE (CONT’D) I thought it would blow over. You know, ‘It'll be okay tomorrow.’ Or next week. And suddenly there's no tomorrow. Laine looks at Trevor. She is sick with guilt.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Laine, you can’t blame yourself for this. Friends have arguments. Why Debbie did what she did... we’ll never know.  14. Quiet. Laine keeps looking at the board.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Sit across from me a sec. Trevor gives her a look -- knows where she’s going with t LAINE (CONT’D) You aren’t supposed to mess with it alone.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You said it was a game.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It is. But... Trevor sits across from her. Watches as Laine puts her fingertips on the planchette. He does the same.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: You do two circles like this. One for each of us. Clockwise. They move the planchette twice around the board. The feel in the room shifts. Trevor gives Laine her space, knows s needs to say some things. LAINE (CONT’D) Freshman year, when my mom suddenly decided that she needed to ‘find herself’ and split on us, I was a total mess. You get your world ripped out from you like that -- you don’t know if you can trust anyone again. And Deb... she pulled me out of it. It wasn’t anything she said or did -- it was her just being there. Always there. Trevor trades a quiet look with Laine, moved by her words LAINE (CONT’D) I never got to say ‘goodbye.’ Together their hands move the planchette to the words GOO BYE at the bottom of the Ouija board. Overcome with sadne Laine can barely say the words... LAINE (CONT’D) Goodbye, Debbie.  15. INT. LAINE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Laine’s back home. Alone in her room. And she now has the OUIJA with her. She sets the board on her desk. Slides th planchette on GOOD BYE at the bottom. Laine lights a voti candle next to the board. A remembrance. TIME LAPSE DISSOLVE... as the candle burns low... flicker out... the light in the room fading on the board. INT. LAINE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT It’s late. The room sits in darkness. We’re on the Ouija board... the planchette still rests on the words GOOD BYE DRIFT OVER TO LAINE. Asleep. We hover above the bed as... .-..-very slowly... almost imperceptibly... the bedside t begins to slide away from the bed. Laine wakes up. Listening in the dark as she hears someth moving in her room. Laine sits up, reaches over for her lamp... and it’s not there. She looks over to see that her bedside table is no three feet away from the bed. The light cord from the lam swings slightly. And that sound comes again. SCRAAAAPE... something else i sliding around in the room. Laine gets out of bed, turns on the lamp -- and the sound immediately stops. Laine steps over to see the OUIJA BOARD on the desk where left it. But something looks different. The planchette ha moved... no longer on GOOD BYE at the bottom of the board Laine stands right over the board... sees that the planch is now on top of the letter ‘D.’ Laine is chilled by the sight of it. She cautiously reach out and touches the planchette... glances around her room ‘what just happened?’ INT. LAINE’S BEDROOM - DAY Morning. Laine’s getting dressed as Sarah shuffles past i the hallway... just now waking up.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Hey, Worm -- Sarah pokes her head in. LAINE (CONT’D) -- were you in my room last night?  16.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Wait. What? --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- were you messing around in here. Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No. God. I wasn’t in here. You're trippin’. Sarah moves on. Laine stands there, looking down at the Ouija.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local hangout. Family-owned kind of place. Laine sits wit Trevor and Isabelle at a booth. Isabelle wears a waitress uniform, taking a break from her shift. Laine is in the middle of her story --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- and then the planchette had moved to the letter ‘D.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: The board must've gotten bumped --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- it did not get bumped, Trevor. Stuff was moving in my room. Trevor reaches across the table... takes Laine’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Laine. Everyone’s in shock. But you don’t need to keep feeling guilty about this. Last night... you were having some crazy nightmare. Laine's frustration is growing. She pulls her hands away.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I wasn't asleep. It’s Debbie. She's trying to contact me. Isabelle and Trevor exchange a worried look. Isabelle tri a softer approach --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Let's say she is. What do you think she wants? Laine looks at them. Very serious.  17.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: She wants me to play the game.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Are you being for real? Laine fights her emotions. Trying not to fall apart.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: You ever think that even after someone you love has died... there’s still a way they can reach out? What if the game is real this time? I need to talk to Debbie. Please. Do this with me. The COOK at the kitchen window hits the bell. DING! Order up. Aman in a tie -- ISABELLE’S FATHER -- angrily waves a her to get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Of course... I’m in. Trevor nods, uncomfortable about this.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Me too. EXT. LAINE’S HOUSE - DAY Laine stands out at the curb as her FATHER finishes loadi suitcase and hanging bag into the back of a waiting TAXI Mr. Moreno closes the trunk, comes over to Laine.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORENO
dialogues.text: I hate to leave right now.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: We'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORENO
dialogues.text: Once these permits get approved, I‘ll be back. Might be a few days though. Laine nods. MR. MORENO (CONT’D) Nona will drop by, check in on you guys -- but you know she can’t keep up with Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I got it covered. He gives her a smile, but his eyes are filled with worry.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MORENO
dialogues.text: Love you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Love you too, Papi. CLOSE UP OF A BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO. Artistic. Half of Laine’s face and half of Debbie’s face. Side by side. Staring right at the camera. INT. LAINE’S ROOM - NIGHT From the photo on her wall collage, EASE OVER to find Lai at her desk... looking down at the OUIJA BOARD. Beat, the she places the board into her backpack and zips it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah's on the living room couch. History textbook open. Notes. Studying hard. Laine steps in, backpack over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: C’mon. I have to run out. I’m dropping you off at Nona’s.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Laine, I’m totally in the middle of this. Dad put me on blast, so look -- I’m studying. Laine regards her sister for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: One hour and I’1l be back. There's some dinner stuff in the fridge. Sarah, do you hear me? Sarah barely looks up from her book.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: One hour. I got it. Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laine comes out of the house... takes a few steps down he walkway. Glances over -- -- to see that same CAR Sarah got out of the other night parked in front of the house next door. Lights off, but music playing inside. BASS THUMPING. Laine starts walking toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Hey! I see you, asshole!  19. Laine has a plastic water bottle and throws it at the car THUNK. The car lights quickly turn on -- engine revs and vehicle peels out. Sarah storms out of the house, furious.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: -- the hell, Laine!

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: For a minute there I actually had a little faith in you. Sarah’s a swirl of fury and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We hang out -- what’s wrong with that?!

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong is that you’re fifteen and whoever that dude is should know better. Alright. Since you can’t be left alone, you're coming with me.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?! I’m not going anywhere. Laine goes quiet... and then --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: You know what? I’11 let Dad deal with it. I think he said if you slipped up again -- at all -- you'd have to go to that special school. You know, where they send the ‘problem kids.' I'm sure it's nice. Oh, but remember, when you have to use pepper spray on your fellow classmates, extend your arm away from your face. INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT LOOKING DOWN FROM AN UPSTAIRS WINDOW. Laine moves through the dark backyard past the covered pool... followed by Trevor, Isabelle and Sarah. Linger here. At the side of the window, what we thought w the edge of the curtain suddenly MOVES. Someone steps away... sinking back into the shadows of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furniture sitting in the dark. Hold for a long beat...  20. .»..as LAINE enters the quiet space. She glances around, passes the vintage clock she looked at before... making s the coast is clear. She turns and signals to the others w are waiting by the back in the kitchen. They all step further inside. Isabelle turns on a lamp --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: This feels wrong. We shouldn’t be here. -- Trevor comes up behind Isabelle, turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No house lights. We don’t want to draw attention. Trevor pulls an LED camping lantern from his backpack and turns on the low light.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I thought we’d do this up in her room. That’s where we used to play. Sarah steps over to Trevor -- an aside.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you think you’re gonna ‘talk’ to someone with that thing. (going into a little routine) ‘Yo. Can you hear me now? Signal’s bad. I’m only getting like one bar here.’

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Your sister needs to do this. Just zip it and go along.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll lead the way. Sarah takes Trevor’s lantern, heads for the stairs. INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - NIGHT Sarah is ahead of the others. Moving down the dark upstai hallway. We follow her into -- INT. DEBBIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sarah comes into the room. She shines the lantern around. Looks at the tree mural across the wall. FOLLOW THE LANTE LIGHT, scanning things on Debbie’s shelves, over to the b -- and SOMEONE’S SITTING RIGHT THERE IN THE DARK!  21. SARAH SCREAMS! Drops the lantern. Backs away. Laine, Isabelle and Trevor hurry into the room to find Sa standing with her back against the wall. Staring. Laine follows her gaze -- as the PERSON sitting on the bed now stands... steps further into the light. It’s the loner GUY who Laine saw at Debbie’s wake. This i PETE (17).

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR LAINE
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you -- -- what’re you doing up here?! Pete coolly takes them in. Not ruffled in the slightest.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Everyone just chill.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You got three seconds to answer me --

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: -- I’m Pete. Friend of Debbie’s from theater class. Transferred in last fall.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- she never talked about a 'Pete. I think I'd know if you were friends. Pete regards Laine.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Laine, right? Heard all about you from Debbie... the falling out you guys had. How you stopped talking to her. Laine's stung by his comment. A beat and then Pete holds a DVD.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In answer to your questions, I told Debbie’s folks I’d burn a DVD of her last performance. Promised to drop it off. I didn’t know they were already gone. (beat) Back door was unlocked, so...

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Fine. But why are you in Debbie's room? Pete glances over at the CLOSET.  22.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Guess I wanted to see where it happened. Still can’t believe she would do that... The room finally settles. Pete connects a look with Laine

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your turn. What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Laine, you don’t have to tell him anything. Pete’s eyes fall on the OUIJA board in Laine’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That’s hers, right? Last couple of weeks, she talked a lot about that game. Beat. Laine can’t hide her surprise at this new info.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Did you ever play it with her?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No. She wanted me to. Bugging me about it... and then she quit asking. Said she found another friend to play with. Pete glances at all of their faces.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s why you’re here. Gonna try to talk to Debbie. A beat and then Pete hands Laine the DVD.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I’1l1 let you guys do your thing. If you can get this to her parents, I'd appreciate it. Pete heads out of the room. INT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY As Pete heads toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Hold up. Pete stops as Laine approaches. It’s just the two of them  23. LAINE (CONT’D) She really wanted you to play? Off his expression we go -- THE FLOOR. Laine sets up the OUIJA BOARD. Places the camping lantern next to it. Just the right amount of ligh Trevor adjusts his VIDEO CAMERA on a tripod, aiming it do on the Ouija board. He glances back at Pete, and then com down next to Laine. Very quiet --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: We don’t even know this guy... Laine cuts a look at Pete. He’s at Debbie’s desk, browsin through her things.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: But Debbie did... she wanted him to play. The more of her friends around the board, the more likely we make contact. (beat) You finish setting up the camera?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. We're all ready. INT. DEBBIE’S ROOM - NIGHT Everyone’s now gathered in a circle around the Ouija boar Sarah starts to touch the planchette, but Laine stops her

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: The rules first. You can’t ever break them. For starters... never play Ouija in a graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Okay. Obviously we’re good there.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Don’t ask for any physical signs -- it should only be questions and answers. Always end a session with ‘good bye.’ And the most important one -- do not play alone. Pete reaches a hand in. The first to touch the planchette He’s ready. Hesitant vibe in the room -- OVERHEAD. THE BOARD. As everyone else puts a hand on the planchette. Fingertips touching.  24. LAINE (CONT’D) We circle the board five times to begin. Once for each of us. The planchette circles the board five times clockwise... comes to rest at the center. Laine takes a breath... her words are like a summoning. T painted tree limbs of Debbie’s wall mural stretched out behind her. LAINE (CONT’D) As friends we've gathered, hearts are true. Spirits near, we call to you. (beat) If there is a presence here, please make yourself known. Nothing happens. The planchette is totally still. Isabell and Trevor trade a side glance, just wanting this to be o Laine remains focused on the board, asks again -- LAINE (CONT’D) Is there a presence among us? Another long moment passes. And then...

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I feel something.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Feel what? Nothing’s happening. We ever so slightly PUSH IN ON THE BOARD -- and the planchette starts moving. Slowly at first. The movement i stuttered... tentative. But definitely moving.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: C’mon. Who’s doing that?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Not me. The planchette keeps moving into the upper left hand corn of the board, stopping on the word YES.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Can you tell us who you are? Beat... then the planchette slides over to the ‘D.’ Laine eyes widen. She’s breathless.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It’s her. I told you. I told you she was here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (out into the room) Debbie... talk to us. With eerie movement, the planchette LITERALLY STARTS TO T UNDERNEATH THE PLAYERS’ FINGERS. Like it’s pointing in a direction... then moves with a sudden quickness to the le ‘H’... now over to ‘I.’ LAINE (CONT’D) She’s spelling something. EVERYONE WATCHES... their faces bathed in the cool blue L light of the camping lantern, as -- -- the planchette glides across the board. More letters. Each one coming faster: F-R-E... (Visual note: we won’t show every letter when the Ouija i spelling out messages. The game sessions will always be a combination of fast stylistic shots of seeing certain let appear in the planchette window, and characters talking o the messages as they happen.) VIDEO CAMERA FOOTAGE. That fixed angle on the tripod. Looking down at the circle of players... hands on the planchette... as the game piece moves uncannily again to letter ‘D.'’ And stays there. Finished with the message. Everyone's fingertips remaining on the planchette. Sarah fully engaged now --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It spelled ‘hi friend.’ ON LAINE -- astonishment filling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Hi friend. Isabelle and Trevor trade that worried look again. Isabel asks a question, pretending that she believes in this --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Laine thinks you’re trying to make contact. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Have you been in my room -- was that you last night? The planchette TWITCHES, then slowly slides again to YES. LAINE (CONT’D) Is there something you're trying to tell me?  26. The planchette TWITCHES again under their fingers, moves the number ‘3’... now over to another number -- ‘0.’ Pete watches -- trying to follow it all.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It’s a number. ‘306.’ NOW LETTERS... the planchette criss-crossing the board an then coming to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: And ‘BD Y.’

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What does that mean? ‘Body’? Or initials? Somebody you know? Laine shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Debbie? Deb... I want to understand. Trevor sees the hope in his girlfriend’s eyes. It’s killi him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay. I think we’re done here --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- No. We can’t stop. Not now. VIDEO CAMERA FOOTAGE. Trevor looks up into the lens, with his free hand, uses his remote to widen out the angle on room. We stay in VIDEO CAMERA MODE --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: This isn't real. And if it is, I need some proof --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: -- Whoa. What do you mean proof?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I want Debbie to show us that she's here. C'mon. Show us something --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- Trevor! That's breaking a rule. You can't ask for a physical sign.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No. It's me asking to see something that’s not this guy pushing the planchette around --  27. Trevor's glaring at Pete as he says this.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: -- wait. You think I'm doing this? Isabelle is starting to grow uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: -- let's just say ‘goodbye’ and end the game. There's a sound out in the house. A low CREAKING. Everyon falls silent. Listening... listening... and -- BAM! OUR POV suddenly shakes. Like the camera's been hit hard. THE POV TIPS BACK ON THE TRIPOD -- FALLS! CRASHING THE FLOOR. We're staring up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who knocked the camera over?! Shadows on the ceiling as Trevor comes running over. Pick us up. Checking the camera.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: It's okay. Still working -- TREVOR SWINGS THE CAMERA AROUND. On the floor, the planchette has been knocked off the Ouija board. Sweep around to see that everyone's on their feet. Rattled. But Laine’s not with the group.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laine? The camera eventually finds Laine... out in the upstairs hall. Standing there very still.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is it -- Laine holds her hand out to silence him. She's trying to hear something. We move out into the hallway. Laine points toward the stairs -- angle turns -- where we hear faint CHIMING MUSIC coming from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: You hear that? Laine moves down the hall and disappears around the corne the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Laine --  28. Sarah steps up, holding the camping lantern. Trevor turns Pete --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- dude, you got a friend down there or something?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I came solo -- swear.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Laine! There's no answer from below... Trevor takes the lantern from Sarah, moves out in front o the others with the light... ...the lantern light pushes into the shadows ahead. Past framed photos of Debbie hanging on the staircase wall. Th further we go, the more distinct that MUSIC becomes. A delicate and haunting melody. Trevor arrives DOWNSTAIRS, catching his reflection in a hanging wall mirror. Across the room, we see Laine standi next to the VINTAGE ANNIVERSARY CLOCK. Mechanisms turn inside the glass dome as the MUSIC plays. Trevor approaches Laine. She keeps staring at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: This was broken since we were kids... hasn't worked in years. And then the MUSIC winds down... stops. Laine looks away from the clock, talking out into the downstairs. Urgent.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deb. I know it's you. You're right here with us. Tell me what you want me to do.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: It’s not her --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- then how do you explain this?!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Guys... where's Pete? CAMERA PANS around... and Pete's missing. It's just the f of them.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pete?  29. The house is so quiet now...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I thought he was standing right -- SMASH! A shattering sound rips through the darkness! It JOLTS everyone. Trevor loses his grip on the camera for a moment. It bobbles. Finally re-adjusts, and now we're FOLLOWING THE OTHERS THROUGH THE HOUSE. Passing furniture the dark. Searching. (A LOW BATTERY warning starts flashing on the upper part the camera screen.) Around a corner. There's Pete in a downstairs hallway. Blood on his shirt. He looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Oh my god you're bleeding! On the floor, large pieces of a BROKEN MIRROR. Shattered. CAMERA CATCHES SIGHT OF PETE'S HAND -- a DEEP RED SLICE across his palm.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I saw someone...

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Where?! Pete points to a shadowed corner.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Standing right there. CAMERA PANS OVER... lantern light aims that way as well.. blowing out the shadows. Just an empty corner.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw a reflection... in the mirror. And then it fell. I was reaching out -- Pete stands there in the hall... apart from the others. Battery warning BEEP. And then picture goes out. BLACK. OUT OF THE DARKNESS, a light breaks through. Shining brighter. FLARING OUT. PULL BACK. It’s a porch light, finally revealing -- EXT. LAINE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Laine stands at her front door with Trevor. She’s still wired from playing the game, holding Trevor's video camer  30.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Can I hang on to this? I want to go through the footage. Take another look at her messages. Trevor doesn’t say anything. Laine looks up at him and se his expression. Hard to read.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I’m worried about you. That you need this game to mean something.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: You were there. You saw what happened tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. And that guy Pete was there too. I don’t know what he’s up to, but he’s messing around with your head. You believe that he saw someone in the house... the mirror just falling like that?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: His hand. Why would he do that to himself? Trevor shrugs... gazes off.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I mean... we really don't know what he was doing there tonight. Do we? Laine doesn't answer. Because Trevor's right -- she doesn know. Trevor gives her a kiss, but he’s preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Night. Laine heads inside. Closes the door. We hear it LOCK from the inside. Trevor heads back to his car. His keyless ent CHRIPS. He’s about to get in... taking one last look arou The nighttime street is totally empty... no one around. And yet, something feels changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls dressed for Phys Ed stream out of the locker room, tossing a volleyball around. Laine’s the last one. Headin to join the others on the field when --  31.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laine. Laine turns. Sees Pete standing there behind the bleacher He approaches. Laine glances at his bandaged hand. It's awkward between them.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: How's your hand?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Better. Thanks. Pete stands there. Uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last night... with the game. What do you think really happened? Laine doesn't say anything. Cautious. Pete keeps going...

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I was reading these theories about the Ouija. One of them said it’s our subconscious minds moving the planchette. You know? Involuntary motor muscles kick in and we're just telling ourselves what we want to believe. (beat) There are only two things it can be. Either our minds are playing tricks on us... or we were really talking to Debbie last night. Laine regards Pete... and then she breaks. Putting her tr feelings out there.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I believe it was her. Pete quietly nods... turns away. Like he's trying to hold back his emotions. LAINE (CONT’D) Did you like her? You know... more than friends?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We hung out in class. She always said I was a good listener. Yeah. I thought maybe there could be more between us. That I should ask her out. But I never did... (beat) Deb used to talk about you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The day you guys had that fight, she was upset. Whatever went down -- not my business. But all the stories she told me, the good times -— - feels like I already know you. We hear Isabelle SHOUTING from the field --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laine -- let’s go! Laine glances over toward the field... suddenly feeling isolated back here with Pete behind the bleachers. The tw of them are out of view of the others.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I should go. Pete takes a step toward her. Standing very close now.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Laine, what do you think Debbie’s trying to tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STUDENTS at work on an assignment, but Laine’s turned awa from her computer. Looking down at the palm of her hand. CLOSER WITH LAINE. The Ouija message from last night writ in pen on her hand: 30 6BD/Y.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laine has snuck out of class, moving with purpose down th empty hallway. Whispering numbers --
Laine scans down a row of STUDENT LOCKERS. Stops at --

REVEAL that Laine is standing in front of locker #306. Remnants of a makeshift memorial. Notes. Wilted flowers stuck in the locker vents. It’s Debbie’s locker. Combination lock still attached. Laine looks back at the message written on her hand: BD Y LAINE (CONT’D) ‘B-Day.’ Debbie’s birthday. Laine enters a series of numbers and CLICK -- to her astonishment -- the lock falls opens. Laine hesitates...  33. glances around the hall... wondering if she should even b doing this. LAINE (CONT’D) This is crazy... SOMEPLACE DARK. A metallic rattle, a door opens... light spilling in. We’re deep inside Debbie’s locker, looking o at Laine. Linger here for a moment, then -- WITH LAINE -- as she checks things out. A messy math BIND Graded papers in folders. A couple cans of Red Bull.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want me to find... Laine keeps digging. Pushes aside a sweater in the back o the locker to find a black and white marbled NOTEBOOK. Notebook pages flip to reveal... doodles... to-do lists.. math scratch paper. Nothing of significance. Laine keeps flipping... ...suddenly stops on a detailed sketch of a OUIJA BOARD. as Laine slowly turns the page, there’s more. VINTAGE PHO COLLAGES of people playing Ouija. Eerie images printed fr the internet that depict seance type gatherings and spiri contact. This wasn’t done in the name of art. It feels li the outward signs of an increasing obsession. JOURNAL ENTRIES and dates are mixed in with the images. Debbie’s handwriting. Laine reads a passage quietly to herself as her face fills with deep concern.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Laine... what are you doing? Laine turns and sees the history teacher, MR. SATLOF, standing at the end of the hall, watching her intently.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Nothing... Laine closes the locker, shutting us back into the DARKNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of day. Most of the cars already gone from the parkin lot. We find TREVOR, Isabelle, AND LAINE hanging out by Isabelle’s car. Trevor has his bike out, resting against CLOSER WITH THEM. They’re flipping through DEBBIE’S JOURN LAINE (CONT’D) Her journal... the whole thing. Every word’s about playing the game with some friend. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAINE (CONT’D) Over and over again. Listen to this... (Laine reads) ‘,..he's changed. Started acting really weird. I don't want to play with him anymore. I'm going to tell him tonight that it's over.’ Trevor takes the journal and flips to the next page to fi it blank.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That was her last entry... written the day she died. (to Laine) And you’re sure she never says a name of who she’s playing with...

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: No. Like she was keeping a secret. Isabelle swallows.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What if Debbie wasn’t alone that night? They all absorb the impact of this.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That Pete guy. Maybe he was with her --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- we don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I got an idea. How about we just walk away from all of this.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I’m not walking away from Debbie. Not again. (beat) If we figure out who this friend is -- we figure out what really happened to Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Laine and Sarah’s grandmother NONA moves through t house with a laundry basket. Spanish language TV on in th background. She picks up a stray sock on the stairs... an notices another sock further up.

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: These girls...  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nona retrieves the other sock at the top of the stars, an she looks down the hall... .»..sees that pieces of laundry are scattered on the floo like a trail leading to Laine’s closed bedroom door. Nona feels a chill. She puts the basket down, moves down hall, stopping at Laine’s door. She hesitates at the door... then pushes it open. INT. LAINE’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Nona steps into Laine’s room and sees that the trail of clothes continues across her floor to the bed. UNDER THE BED... as NONA comes closer. Picking up the clothes. Closer... BACK WITH NONA. She gets down on her hands and knees, sta to lift the dust ruffle when behind her -- a SCRAPING SOU Nona turns. Just as the Ouija planchette falls off the de and lands on the floor. She picks it up. Confused. And as she stands she sees the OUIJA BOARD on the desk. In an instant, she realizes what she’s holding and drops it. Backing away from the board right into -- Laine. Home fro school. Both of them scaring the hell out of each other.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Nona, what’re you doing -- Nona points at the Ouija board... but won’t look at it.

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: -- you should never touch such things, let alone bring one into your house --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- it was Debbie's. It's just a game. That's all. Nona -- Nona’s doesn’t want to hear it. She’s out of the room. Muttering something to herself. Laine picks up the planchette from the floor. Beat, and we’re -- SUDDENLY TIGHT ON TREVOR. Sweating. Breathing. His face a mask of total concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor bikes along the outer edge road of a neighborhood. traffic out here. Body leaning forward on the bike.  36. Pushing hard. A little further. Reaching a mental finish line... and then he coasts. Sits up. Catching his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor takes a sip of water... walks his bike to the entr of a long pedestrian tunnel. HOLD HERE... as Trevor enter and slowly disappears into the shadows ahead. INT. PEDESTRIAN TUNNEL —- DAY Bike gears clickclickclick as Trevor makes his way throug the narrow tunnel... light fading on him as he goes deepe Up ahead, a sound coming from around a tunnel corner. . - -SCRATCH-SCRATCH-SCRATCH-SCRATCH. Trevor stops. Silencing the clicking of his bike so he ca hear better. The SCRATCHING gets louder... like nails on a chalkboard echoing in this concrete corridor.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Hey -- somebody there? No answer... but something MOVES. An abandoned SHOPPING C slowly rolls out from behind the corner... drifts to a st Trevor peers ahead into the darkness. Can’t see around th corner up ahead. Was it the wind... or did someone push i TREVOR (CONT’D) Who is that? The cart just sits there. Trevor leans his bike against t wall and unclips a safety light from under the seat. He starts walking toward that corner. Coiled. On edge. His red light BLINKING into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pete? I swear to god dude -- He quickly rounds the corner -- and _no one’s there. Trev regards the empty tunnel... his light still blinking when suddenly -- a small ROCK comes skipping out of the darkne landing at his feet. Like someone just tossed it. Trevor picks up the rock. Rattled. He moves toward the direction it came from... notices a sign on the tunnel wa PLAYGROUND -- with an arrow pointing to the exit. Trevor runs his light across the sign, revealing that it’s been vandalized. Some of the letters wildly scratched off. Just the word PLAY remains.  37. Trevor raises his blinking light toward the empty darknes ahead of him where the rock came skittering in from. He starts to back away... unaware that in the brief flashes red light -- -- SOMEONE IS BEHIND HIM. Just a shape. And Trevor is backing up right toward them. Closer. CLOSER. He turns -- -- and it’s just empty tunnel. His bike leaning against t wall. Trevor stares. Can’t shake the feeling that he wasn alone here. INT. NONA’S APARTMENT - DAY Laine comes inside with her grandmother. Turns on some lights. It’s a comfortable apartment. The decor reflects Nona’s life and heritage. Laine and her grandmother say nothing. Then, in Spanish -

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: The board. You used it. Didn't you -- to try to contact your friend? Laine hesitates. Then --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It was just once. Nona touches the small gold cross that dangles from her n

dialogues.speaker: NONA
dialogues.text: Do not turn to divination for answers. There are things beyond us that we must simply leave alone. Promise, Elena. You get rid of it. Never touch it again. Nona’s warning hangs heavy in the air. INT. LAINE’S CAR - DAY Laine sits in her parked car outside her grandmother’s apartment building. Conflicted. She glances over, the corner of DEBBIE’S JOURNAL sticking out of her backpack. MOMENTS LATER. Laine still in her car. Flipping through t pages of the journal. She can’t pull herself away from th She studies a page that has OUIJA MESSAGES jotted down. T word fragments make no sense. Laine writes one of them ou on a piece of paper trying to decipher it...

dialogues.speaker: FNS HGME
dialogues.text: Laine’s cell phone suddenly vibrates on the dashboard, shaking her from her thoughts. She answers --  38.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Sure. Of course -- I’1ll go check right now. EXT. DEBBIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Evening has fallen. Laine pulls up to DEBBIE'S HOUSE and the sweep of headlights sees a WOMAN standing out in the yard, looking up at the house. Laine gets out of her car and approaches the WOMAN. It’s MRS. GALARDI. Just standing there.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Galardi -- your husband’s been looking all over for you. Mrs. Galardi points toward an upstairs window. Riveted.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: I saw her... up in the window. A chill runs through Laine as she looks up at the window. But it’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It’s just the curtain. Laine tries to guide Mrs. Galardi away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told Mr. G. I’d wait with you here. He’s going to take you back to your sister’s. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: What if Deborah’s still in the house... and she needs me...

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: There’s nothing for you in there. Promise me you won’t go in the house.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: I’ve been having these dreams. Debbie’s in her room... and someone’s in there with her. And my baby... she’s screaming... but I can’t hear her. Mrs. Galardi turns and takes Laine’s hand -- holds it tig looking right at her with wild eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GALARDI
dialogues.text: No one can hear her.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY, and quietly, we’re on a CHAIR. It just sits the EASE IN on the legs of the chair... as it starts to move. sliding across the floor. IN THE EMPTY DINER, WE FIND ISABELLE in her waitress unif She pulls chairs out and flips them upside down on a tabl Sweeping underneath. Closing up for the night. She heads toward the back, but stops at the daily special board. A prankster has obviously rearranged the letters f “Try Our Meatballs” to “Eat Our Balls.”

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: That’s lovely. She puts the letters back in place. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle ties off a large bag of garbage... heads toward rear exit... passes her FATHER in the restaurant office a runs through the receipts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle comes out the back exit... nudges a brick agains the bottom of the door to keep it open. She takes the sack of garbage over to the dumpster and he it in. DRIFT AWAY FROM HER... .».-over to the back door. As the brick door-stop begins slide across the ground. Sliiiding and -- SHHHUNK. Isabelle turns to see the door has fallen shut. She steps away from the dumpster and comes over to the do Tries the handle. No entry from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hey! She KNOCKS on the door. Waiting. Stuck out here alone behind the restaurant. Isabelle glances around. The bulky dumpster... her parked car... sodium vapor lights BUZZING overhead. Not a soul in sight... and yet... there is a presence. Li someone out there is watching. Isabelle BANGS on the door again. More urgent. Doesn’t wa to be out here a second longer. ISABELLE (CONT’D) Dad! C’mon, open up!  40. There’s a faint fluttering sound. Behind her. Isabelle glances back. Sees A FLYER on her car windshield Fluttering in the night breeze. She goes to her car, passing through a pool of overhead light. Takes the flyer off her windshield. Furniture Sale Saturday! She wads it up, and now notices something else. The word ‘FREND’ written in the condensation on the drive side window. The letters drip. Like someone was just here... having written the word with their finger. It seems innocent. Isabelle wipes it away with her hand. Stands there in the dark... As her car ALARM suddenly goes off! Scaring the hell out her. It shrills through the night air. Isabelle takes a step back... something doesn't feel right. The alarm keep BLARING as -- KA-THUNK! The back door finally opens. Light from the restaurant spilling out. We hear her DAD from inside --

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s going on -- you okay? DAD has Isabelle’s car keys. He shuts off the alarm. Silence again. Isabelle takes a final look at her car.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm good. She steps inside and pulls the door closed. EXT. LAINE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Through a window, glimpse SARAH in the living room. Her f bathed in the glow of her laptop screen. A GUY'S VOICE --

dialogues.speaker: GUY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Imagine what could happen if one million minds came together with the same mission. INT. LAINE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Sarah is on her laptop, watching a video on a website. A PODCAST GUY talks about the Ouija, as a ticker runs along top of the screen... 16,209 and counting.

dialogues.speaker: HIP PODCAST GUY
dialogues.text: That’s right, we’re gonna be talking with the spirits. Hit the join button. All you need is your mouse...  41. NOW A “VIRTUAL OUIJA” on the computer screen. A demo show someone with their hand on a mouse, slightly moving... as planchette on the virtual game board also moves.

dialogues.speaker: HIP PODCAST GUY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .».-and you can take part in the world’s biggest Ouija game ever... Sarah slaps her laptop closed.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So lame.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE OUIJA BOARD. Fingertips on the planchette as it moves around to different letters. It’s the VIDEO FOOTAGE from other night. INT. LAINE’S ROOM - NIGHT Laine’s up late. Holding Debbie’s penguin keychain like a worry stone -- watching the Ouija game video on her compu Playing back the part where the camera got knocked over. SCREEN -—

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: If Debbie's really here she can show us --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: -- let's just say ‘goodbye’ and end the game. There's a sound out in the house. A low CREAKING. Then -- BAM! OUR POV suddenly shakes. Like the camera's been hit hard. THE POV TIPS BACK ON THE TRIPOD -- FALLS! CRASHING THE FLOOR. We're staring up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who knocked the camera over?! Laine stops the tape. Silencing the chaotic volume of the game. REWIND. Everything moving in reverse. She hits PLAY again, watching an earlier moment. The argument --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Laine said no physical sign.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So what? I don't see anyone taking their hand away. Laine FREEZES the tape. REWINDS further and REPLAYS. Watching the game as the planchette moves about the board  42. Specifically, she’s watching Pete. Closely. Trying to get read on his facial expressions. Now studying his hand as the planchette spells out a mess starting to wonder if he is making it move. She hits pause. The image freezes between frames. It creates a weird effect... and it makes Pete look strange. His features suddenly menacing. Out in the hall... a floorboard CREAKS. Similar to the so Laine just heard on the video playback.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Sarah? INT. LAINE’S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - NIGHT Laine comes down the hall. So irritated. She opens Sarah' bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Worm, if you’re sneaking out -- But Sarah’s not in her room. Beat... Laine continues down the hall, to THE STAIRS -- and finds Sarah standing a few steps below... quietly staring ahead. From the top of the stairs, Laine can see that the front is wide open, lightly THUMPING against the wall... leaves blowing in across the foyer from the outside. Sarah slowly turns back... looking up at Laine. Quiet --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Someone’s in the house. They hold a rising, terrified look as the sound of someth heavy suddenly SCRAPES on the floor downstairs. Like some accidentally bumped into a piece furniture in the dark. Sarah bolts back up the stairs to Laine -- and together t hurry into -- INT. LAINE’S ROOM - NIGHT Laine silently pulls at Sarah, over to the closet. A hidi spot. The two girls moving quickly -- quietly slipping in the closet. Closing the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very dark in here. Laine and Sarah huddle close in the sm closet. Voices so quiet and scared ---

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ohmygodohmygod...  43.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Shh-shh. Do you have your phone? Good. Call for help.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Who the hell’s in our house?!

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Just call -- Their faces visible in the faint glow of Sarah's cell pho THUD! A sound out in the house. LAINE (CONT’D) Sarah -- hurry.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m trying. Sarah can't even dial her phone. Hands shaking so bad. And now something SLAMS against the closet door! Hands ov their mouths, the girls want to cry out -- but can't. Tak everything they have to hold it in. Another SLAM against the closet door. Sarah drops her pho Laine grabs the closet door handle. Holds it tight. Tryin to keep anyone from getting it open. It’s an excruciating moment. Waiting for what’s next. Breathing hard. Scared to death. And then ALL HELL BREAKS LOOSE on the other side of the d It sounds like someone’s banging on the door with their fists. BAM! BAM! BAM! Over and over and over. Relentless. The CLOSET DOOR RATTLES HARD -- someone’s trying to get i Sarah can't even hold back anymore. She SCREAMS. Falling back into the corner of the closet. Laine holds tight -- with everything she’s got. BAM! BAM! BAM! Louder... LOUDER... SO GODDAMN LOUD! And then -- -- it stops. Completely. All the noise. Silent. The longest beat... the girls hold absolutely still. And then Laine gently turns the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't. Laine does it anyway. Opens the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LAINE’S ROOM - NIGHT The girls emerge from the closet. And even in the dark, right away -- they can tell that something’s different.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Where’s your bed?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Moved. Over there.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Everything's moved. The whole room has been rearranged. But there’s a familiarity about the lay-out of all the furniture. Car lights pass by outside, just for a moment -- casting a lo tree branch shadow across the wall. Laine feels for a light -- CLICK. It’s now set up just like Debbie’s room. Bed. Desk. Side table. Even the OUIJA BOARD is at the center of the floor just like when they play it at Debbie’s house. Sarah takes it all in... reeling.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is so messed up... who would do this? Laine kneels down next to the Ouija board on the floor an sees that the planchette is once again on the letter ‘D.’

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: It’s Debbie. She wants us to play again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corner booth. Away from the other customers. Everyone who played the Ouija is gathered. Except for Pete. Voices hushed. Urgent. Talking over each other --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- and all the furniture had been moved. Arranged just like Debbie's room. The game sitting right there. It was her way of saying we need to come back to the board --

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: -- Laine. Stop it. This isa living breathing person who’s trying to freak us out. The game is not real.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Then how do you explain someone watching me last night, writing messages on my car —-

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: -- it’s Pete. You ever wonder if the guy might be a complete psycho... making us think that it's Debbie doing all this? I mean, what do you want me to say here?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: I want you to say you believe in this. But Trevor won’t give her that. Sarah has remained silent this whole time. Still shaken b the night before. She finally speaks, her voice quiet...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: In our house last night, couldn't have been a person that did all that. It was her. I’m with Laine. We've got to keep going. Isabelle looks at Laine. Puts it out there --

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: You think she's trying to tell us the truth about how she died. Laine holds her look. It's dead quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Someone killed Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Why did we do this? Never should have touched that thing...

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: We have to talk to her. We geta name... and then we’re done. No one says anything. Just an incredible sense of dread i the air. And then jolting us like a clap of thunder -- THE OUIJA BOARD. Larger than life. FOUR HANDS reach in... fingertips touching the planchette. INT. DEBBIE’S ROOM - NIGHT Laine, Trevor, Sarah, and Isabelle sit on the floor in Debbie’s room. A couple of battery lanterns placed about dark room. Everyone has a hand on the planchette.  46.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Four circles this time. One for each of us. They CIRCLE THE BOARD clockwise. One. Two. Three. Four. The game has begun. LAINE (CONT’D) As friends we've gathered, hearts are true. Spirits near, we call to you. If there’s a presence here, make yourself known. Long beat on the board... the planchette totally still.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s not working.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Let me try. Debbie, it’s Iz. Will you come and talk to us? Everybody remains intensely focused. Barely breathing. EA IN on the planchette. Closer and closer... a feeling of passing time... .--and nothing happens. It sits there. Lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: We're doing everything exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Not everything. (beat ) Pete’s not here. Maybe because there were five of us who made initial contact... something about our collective energy. Beat... as Trevor gives Laine a look.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Collective energy. Sure. That’s it. You know what? There’s one way to find out.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Bring Pete here -- what if it’s him doing all this?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Iz. Laine, go ahead. Invite him over.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TIME DISSOLVE. FROM THE SHINING LIGHT OF THE CAMPING
dialogues.text: LANTERN, we drift up to see that PETE is now sitting with others in the circle around the board. He feels the tensi No one’s talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So what’s going on with this little gathering? Seems like the party got started without me. You guys tried to play already, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: We're going to do something different this time, Pete. Trevor has a bandana in his hand. Pete eyes it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Blackout. Okay, so we’re all taking turns... or it’s just for me?

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: For you.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Unless you don’t want to stay. Pete thinks about it --

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Fine. Go ahead. Trevor comes behind Pete. Ties the blindfold over his eye Cinches it tight. Pete’s eyes are completely covered. No way he can see the board. Before they start, Trevor quietly TURNS THE BOARD 180 DEGREES. It’s now upside down for Pete, and he’s unaware.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, Pete. We’re starting. The four friends reach in and put their hand on the planchette. Pete blindly feels out and touches the planchette with his bandaged hand. He’s the last one in. Quiet beat on the Ouija... Then, a TWITCH of the planchette. IT MOVES. Like before, slides across the board to the letter “D.” Laine and the others silently take note... then a suspici glance at Pete with his blindfold. Laine turns her eyes b to the board.  48.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Debbie, we want to help you. Who were you playing with? Who was with you the night you died? The planchette slightly vibrates under their fingers... T QUICKLY SLIDES ALL THE WAY OFF THE BOARD.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Whoa. What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Because he can’t see. So he’s just sliding it off the board --

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: -- I didn’t do that --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: -- Trevor. Stop. Laine moves the planchette back onto the board. LAINE (CONT’D) Give us a name. Who were you with? The planchette just sits there. Everyone staring. Laine takes a breath, tries a new approach. LAINE (CONT’D) If you don’t want to say right now, I understand. How about something else? Just so we know it’s you. The planchette remains still. LAINE (CONT’D) The other night, you moved everything around in my room. A beat... and then the planchette slides to YES. Laine exchanges a look with her little sister. Sees the f on her face.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You really scared Sarah. Let's not do that anymore. The planchette starts to move. H-A-H-A.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: ‘Ha ha...’ Laine suddenly doesn’t feel right about this game. Someth is off.  49.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Debbie. The clock downstairs... remember how it got broken? The planchette just sits there. LAINE (CONT’D) ...when we were kids.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (under his breath) What’re you doing? Laine doesn’t answer. Focused on the board.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Who broke the clock? The planchette hesitates. Then spells: M-E Laine looks up at the others --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was the one who broke the clock. It’s not her... (beat) This isn’t Debbie. SUDDENLY, WE’RE ACROSS THE ROOM. Watching the players fro lurking perspective. Behind Debbie’s bedside table. The lantern right in front of us moves. Just an inch. The pla don’t notice... focused on the game. The lantern moves ag Slowly sliding. It inches across the table and -- -- CRASH! Everyone spins at the sudden sound and sees the fallen lamp on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What the hell was that? Trevor in particular seems alarmed by the incident. He tu back to look at the blindfolded Pete... suddenly not so s of his beliefs anymore. Laine turns back to the planchette. The air feels thick. asks in a cautious tone --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Who is this? Like before, the planchette slides to 'D'... stops for a moment, and then keeps going. Over to 'Z.'

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 'DZ.' We don't know you. We want to talk to Debbie.  50. QUICK MOVEMENTS ACROSS THE BOARD. Letters appear in the planchette window: 2 B AD

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: ‘Too bad.’

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: Did Debbie make contact with you? The board spells out -- M-Y-F-R-E-N-D.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: 'My friend.' A sick realization sets into Trevor’s expression. TREVOR (CONT’D) Wait. Is this who Debbie was talking about? This is the friend. EASE IN ON LAINE... a rising sense of urgency in her ques amidst the revelations --

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
dialogues.text: When the five of us played before... that was you? Planchette slides to YES. MOVE AROUND THE CIRCLE OF PLAYERS. A beat on each of thei faces... now connected to this game more than ever.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the night Debbie died... she was playing the game. She was talking to you. CLOSE ON THE PLANCHETTE. Totally still... and then it sta to VIBRATE HARD. Literally RATTLING against the board. Everyone stares, keeping their fingers in place. This is something new. Pete sits there with his blindfold in plac Getting tense at only being able to hear. LAINE (CONT’D) Did you kill her? The lights from the surrounding lanterns begin to BRIGHTE A LOW GROANING SOUND coming from somewhere deep in the ho Pete rips the blindfold off. Can’t take it anymore. Desperate to see what’s going on. Isabelle closes her eyes, saying a prayer to herself.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Please forgive us for what we have done... But Laine keeps pressing. Has to know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: LAINE
